publicationStmt.publisher: Manuscript Pamphleteering in Early Stuart England (MPESE)

body.head: Supposed to be by Dr Brownrigge
body.p:
Answer
I have not ye bookes to searth into those statutes, nor have I seene ye
petition of right But that ye King may authorize vnder his great Seale ye admi-
nistring of an oath (as this hee doth) appeares in his making of Incorporations
and giueing them power to sweare ye members of them to ye statutes of those In-
corporations: The Oath against Simoney is thus authorized in King Ieames his
booke of Canons Can 40, Oour Oath in ye Vniversity, and in perticuler Colledges
have noe other warrant. 2ly Suppose by ye lawes of ye Land ye giving of
such oathes ware vnlawfull yet I conceive, that ye Statutes make such oathes
preiudicall to those that administer and impose them, not to those that take
them being imposed.

2 Answer.
The clause of ye oath to which this doubt refirrs, I conceiue to be this,
I doe approoue ye doctring and discipline or Goverment established in ye
Church of England, as containing all things necessary to salvation: By which
words it appeares that ye doctrine of the church of England is by the oath
acknowledged, to containe all fundamentall truthes, and not to be wanting or
defectiue in any truth necessary to salvation: So that whether this clause
respect only ye 39 Articles, or any other publike and authorized explanation
of any perticuler truth noe man can conceiue, that there is wanting eyther
in the one or in ye other any truth which is necessary to salvation, And further
ye Oath extends not 2ly when it is said that our doctrine conteines
all things necessary to salvation, it is not to be thought, that we esteeme
every truth taught and established by our church to bee necessary to salvati
on, but onely yt in ye body of sacred truth established in our church, there are
all, and every necessary saveing truth conteined, though over, and above, there
are many other profitable truthes acknowledged, and established, which are
not of fundamentall necessity to salvation 3ly: By Discipline in the place
are not vnderstood ye Canons of ye church, appointing rites, and ceremo-
nyes for order, and decency, which ye Church never intended to make vnchange
able, as Appeares in ye preface to ye Common prayer booker concerning ceremo-
nies, and in ye 34 Article: And to prevent any mistake herein, and for clearing
of the meaning of ye word, Discipline, ye other word Goverment was purposte-
ly added for explanation, whereby this Synod vnderstood, ye parte of Ecclesiasticall
discipline, which consistes of ye severall Governours, and officers of ye Church,
as Arch-Bishops, Bishops, Deanes, Arch-deacons, ye abolishing of these gover-
nours, ye Synod intended to prevent by ye Oath but not to make ye Ca-
nons concerning rites, and ceremonies vncapable of alteration.

3 Answer
First, suppose that clause (all things necessary to salvation) referr onely to ye
doctrine of ye Church expressed in ye 39 Articles, yet ye lawfullnes of ye
Oath hath warrent from thence being in ye 36 Article ratified and authori-
zed. 2ly I see not why wee may not conceive ye sense of ye words now
in doubt to be taken conjunctim comprehending both doctrine, and discipline
or goverment, for vnderstanding of which, we must grant that a lawfull
ministery is in a great degree necessary to ye being of A church to ye preach-
ing of ye word, And administration of ye Sacramtents. And in what
degree ye preaching of ye word, And administration of ye Sacraments, are
necessary; in ye same degree is A lawfull ministery necessary, soe that when we
say, that ye discipline, or goverment, of ye church by Bishops containe some
thinges necessary to salvation, wee only acknowledge that ye Bishops are,
and have power to ordaine A lawfull Ministery, Not but that other Churches
have a lawfull Ministery allso, although not soe regularly, and according to ye
practise of ye Primitive church established amongst them.

4 Answer
First by consent is ment A p Active, operative consent concurring to
alter ye goverment of which implyes willingnesse, desire, endeavour, and vo-
ting such A change 2ly, The promise of not giveing such consent to ye
altering of ye goverment of ye Church established by Arch-Bishops Bishops
Deanes Archdeacons may well be conceived to be absolute, and not Conditio
nall 3ly Hence it followes, not, that A man taking his Oath shall
bee inforced to goe contrary to ye Oath of Alegiance and supremacy, and
to resist Authority, because there is A middle way betweene those two
extremities of consenting, or resisting; Namely, in case such an alteration
should be brought uppon ye Church though I may not consent to it by
vertue of this oath, nor yet oppose, and resist ye Kinge when he shall
doe it, by verute of any Allegiance yet I may patiently submitt to it./

5 Answer
The Calling of Bishops hath much more evidence in Theology, and antiqui
ty for ye warrent of it, then ye calling of Deanes, and Archdeacons, for
which nothing is nor can bee alleadged, but onely Canonicall, and Ecclesiasti
call constitution, yet they being usefull, and expedient helpes for ye gover
ment of ye Church, and soe for A longe time approoved, ye alteration
and removeall of them may well bee provided against, together with ye
more principall and primitive goverment of Bishops./

6 Answer.
I conceiue those wordes (as it stands now established) have reference of
ye Former legall establishment, of Episcopall goverment, before this Synod
was call'd, The Synod adding noe other establishment, but requiring the
oath of recognition, which is but an affirmation of what was formerly
in being in ye Church, And I swearing not to alter ye goverment, As it
is now established, That particle, Now, in all good construction, is Antecedent
to ye oath as being part of ye matter uppon which ye oath passeth,
and soe is presupposed before ye oath is taken, otherwise it is not actualy
establisht by ye oath till ye oath be fully performed, and cosumate./

2ly These words, and as by right it ought to stand, are generall tearmes
importing ye lawfull appiontment of these severall officers, but not determi
ning ye spetiall right uppon which they are grounded, The like mode
ration as ye 36 Article of religion affirmes, That ye consecration of
Bishops is right, orderly, and lawfull, but descends not to any particular
determination of ye kinde of right, and yet wee subcribe to this Arti
ticle, without questioning what is ye speciall right upon which they are
grounded, The like moderation doth ye oath use, not vrging any particular
acknowledgement of this, or that kind of right, but contents it selfe with
generall repressions of right, and lawfullnes, and ye oath running in gener-
all tearmes, obliges noe man further then to ye acknowledgement in gene-
rall; according to ye Kinges declaration before ye Articles, where it is said,
That ye generall meaning of ye Articles of ye church is to be held
without drawing ye Article aside any way, or put any mans private
sense; or Comont, to be ye meaning of ye Article, but it shall bee
taken in ye litterall or gramaticall sense,; soe that hee that holds ye right-
full establishment of this goverment in generall satisfies ye oath.
